roleset.name: one allele transfering a heritable change onto a counterpart allele.

role.descr: paramutable allele (entity changed, also includes mentions of the entire locus/gene)

example.name: paramutate-v
example.text: The seeds obtained from sulf sector (where-1 the sulf allele has paramutated the + Sulf allele *trace*-1) are all sulf/sulf whilst the seeds obtained from the green sectors

example.name: paramutation-n
example.text: The physical pairing could allow the transfer of proteins mediating paramutation from the B' to the B-I allele.

example.name: paramutation-n
example.text: Paramutation of the r1 locus of maize is associated with increased cytosine methylation.
example.arg: of the r1 locus of maize

example.name: paramutated-j
example.text: The paramutated allele itself becomes paramutagenic, that is, capable of epigenetically converting a new paramutable allele.

roleset.note: PARAMUTATION-V NOTES: Added by Julia for clearearth-biotexts.

roleset.name: capable of trasfering a paramutation to another allele

role.descr: paramutable allele (entity changed, also includes mentions of the entire locus/gene or organism)

example.name: paramutagenic-j
example.text: However, paramutagenic alleles of r are not similar in structure to one another.

roleset.note: PARAMUTAGENIC-J NOTES: Added by Julia for clearearth-biotexts.

roleset.name: in a position to be paramutated by another allele

role.descr: paramutable allele (entity changed, also includes mentions of the entire locus/gene or organism)

example.name: paramutable-j
example.text: In some cases, the formerly paramutable allele becomes paramutagenic and can now silence other paramutable alleles; this is called secondary paramutation.

roleset.note: PARAMUTABLE-J NOTES: Added by Julia for clearearth-biotexts.
